I think you missed a great opportunity here to review the chemical makeup of body fat (C18-H34-O2) and how when fat is "burned" it combines with the air we breath to be broken down into 18 Carbon Dioxide molecules (CO2) and 17 Water molecules (H2O) to be breathed out, sweated out, and peed out.

Hint: This is another reason why exercise can assist in a weight loss program, because not only do you burn more calories, but it gives you more opportunity to tell your body to let go of the waste products of fat burning by exhaling and sweating. It's why some people get frustrated when they weight themselves daily while on a weight loss program. You don't lose weight at first; your body holds on to the excess water to see if it's needed. Drinking plenty of water and exercising tells your body, it's not needed, time to let it go.

I think the origin for why this became so popular was that it's best to weigh yourself in the morning, after your morning pee, when doing long-term comparisons. Your body should have reached it's preferred hydration level (meaning, all the excess has been filtered and deposited in the bladder, which you then release, with some exceptions), so your day to day weight should be the closest when compared after that morning pee. Of course fecal material will play a factor, and if you are one of the lucky few who has a strong enough circadian rhythm to poo shortly after waking up, then that would be even more ideal, but for most of us the measurement after urination in the morning will probably be the most stable over time. So when calculating weight loss, you need things as uniform as possible (such as wearing the same clothes each time) to get a better grasp.
Of course some people took the realization that you generally are lightest then and ran with it, expanding with faulty logic and making it into what they claim now. Ok, a milliliter was originally defined as the volume occupied by one gram of water. Modern measurement refinements have changed that in the 5th decimal place, but 1g/ml is still plenty close. 1000 ml is a liter, so that has a mass of 1 kg, which weighs about 2.2 lbs. At 3.8 liters per U.S. gallon, a gallon is about 8.4 pounds (near freezing). 4% less dense near boiling, makes it very close to 8.0. At body temperature of 37 Celsius (98.6 F.), we're in the middle, just above 8 lbs per gallon, around 1 pound per pint.

There's a very old cooking shorthand which says "a pint's a pound the world around". Our bodies are about 70% water, which makes them pretty close to the same density as water. The same approximate rule holds true for most food stuffs, which tend to have similar proportions. Even dry goods are derived from plant stuffs, and tend to retain a density somewhere in that ball park. Weigh a pint of flour sometime. That old rule of thumb wasn't bad for having originated without instrumentation. It simply served to get you closer on average.

2 thoughts...
1. The effect by which a person appears lightest in the morning is also impacted by ambient temperature.  It's usually colder in the morning than at night.  Thus the scale is colder as well.  Cold temp will make the spring in a scales stiffer, and thus will record a lower apparent weight.  (This obviously doesn't impact balance scales, but most home scales utilize a spring).  A high end, non-balance scale (i.e. the one in the picture) may make use of materials to specific minimize this effect, but in cheap, common home scales, this is a significant problem with accuracy.
2. Some of the mass lost at night is actually converted into energy like some of the people in the video speculated.  So they weren't completely wrong.  They just failed to appreciate that this effect is extremely small (i.e. small enough to be unmeasurable) compared to the effect of exhaling CO2.
